comments.author: @ChristopherJamesNeff

comments.text:
@ChristopherJamesNeff  Pretty simple concept. All hardware has a set useful lifespan that can be described as being on a hill.
Great hardware becomes Good hardware.
Good hardware becomes Ok hardware.
Ok hardware becomes Bad hardware.
Bad hardware becomes Shit hardware.
Shit hardware stays Shit hardware.

Where you start on that hill determines heavily how long in this case a GPU will be able to usefully serve you.

So a higher powered card like a 5090 can be reasonably expected to have a better service life than a 5070.

So now you have a card that while it costs $2000 upfront it will last several more years without a upgrade and the cost is spread out. At 5 years it's $400 a year and at 8 years it's down to $250 a year.

A card with a shorter service life will need replacement sooner and thus through nickel and diming will end up outspending the man who paid upfront as the cost of the "cheaper" option continues to go up.
Another way to put is that nothing is more expensive than a cheap solution.
comments.author: @Hybris51129

comments.author: @HistoryDeepDives

comments.text:
@ChristopherJamesNeff  The term "lifespan" in this context is the hardwares ability to do the task you need it to do. If in this case a GPU can't maintain the level of performance you need then it's usefulness to you is at an end unless repurposed. It physically can be in good shape and still functioning but it simply doesn't do the job asked of it.

Now as soon your hardware reaches this point depends on your needs. A 4k 400hz gamer will burn through GPU's quicker than someone who is only using their rig for Facebook for example. These are still just modifiers to where you start on the hardware hill I mentioned earlier.

comments.text:
Could Linus please prove to us somehow which hardware parts are a bottle neck to eachother such as from your RAM to your CPU to your GPU?

 My buddy and I both play Guildwars 2. In certain environments, with our graphics settings turned up as high possible, our systems perform almost identically though he has a vastly newer system with one of the fastest AM4+ CPU's (58003d..ect) and an AMD 6900 XT GPU.

 My systems are an FX 9590 at 4.7ghz, with 2 RX580's in crossfire. And an FX 6350 at 4.5ghz with 1 Nvidia 2070.

 Both of my motherboards only support PCI Express 2.0.

 His would be 3.0 atleast.

 Even with vastly wider bandwidth abilities through all of his hardware, his framereates will still drop to below 40's in Lion's Arch or in BiG zergs or in WvW mode. Mine will get below 30, with the CPU load clearly getting maxed out. Both of us running at 3840x2160 resolution.

 Both of my systems also have virtually identical performance. Especially in Haven DX11 benchmark.

 His system smokes 3 times higher in Haven than both of my systems however.

 I'm really surprised his system is litterally not double or triple the performance of either of my systems, even with this supposedly 'poorly optimized' mmo..

 Are my dual GPU's being bottlenecked by the CPU? My 9590 system does definitely perform measurably better with the 2070..

 Should I still just keep upgrading my GPU or would a new CPU, mobo and RAM really make the difference?

 Guild Wars 2 is the only game to play.

comments.text: Dude, I've watched LTT from the beginning. I just stumbled across the GN vs LTT and ended up going down that rabbit hole. With the water block that started the entire thing, I lost a lot of respect for LTT. When Linus said that he wouldn't pay $100-$500 to remake the video using the correct hardware that the block was built for, but spending $32,000 trying to try to make a computer that would compete with the IMac that's now probably sitting and gathering dust makes no sense. I like most of the tech reviewers and have spent hundreds of hours watching Linus, Pete, Jay, and Steve. But, publicly bashing a start up that sent you their only prototype and telling everyone it's absolutely pointless to pay for when you used the wrong hardware...How does that help the consumers or creators? They might have taken your constructive criticism, refined it, and become a big name in the cooling market...But instead telling millions of people that are subscribed to you that the entire project was pointless and acting like you couldn't afford to fix your mistake is beyond screwed up. You might have crushed someone's career because you are in too much of a rush to put out accurate content. And that's not the only thing that I've noticed over the years. I started building my own pc's because of LTT, and getting COMPLETEY different results on my own builds. I'm certainly no professional builder, but I can't understand how my actual game experience can be so much better than your reviews in many different parts. Many games using the same parts you used in my own build I noticed would get far better fps, temps, and benchmark scores. I can't help but believe Steve on the accuracy of your testing when I've noticed things too, and that LTT basically made a video about how the entire team is wishing they could have more time for testing. I've watched most of LTT videos, but today I'm done with LTT. What you did was wrong and playing the victim makes it worse. Thanks for the good times though.

comments.text:
"1080p Ultra used to cost like... 300 bucks, not 750 bucks"
Sorry, this is some fine nostalgia bullshit you got there.
First off, "used to"... when was that? 10 years ago? 20 years ago? For 10 years ago, add 33% to that due to inflation, putting you at 400 bucks today. For 20 years, make that 67%, which would make that 500. According to your historical pricing chart at the end there, even 15 years ago, the "mid tier" GPU was more than 300 bucks, by the way... and back then, that did not mean "1080p ultra" in the most demanding games of the time.
On top of that "1080p Ultra" is not defined in any sensible way...

For the melting power cables: Since, as I understand it, the card has no way to balance the current over the 6 12V cables it gets, half of a 5090 is still plenty to melt a cable: That's still 280W, 180W more than a single cable is designed to take.

The historical pricing chart is interesting, but you're also giving a grade A example for cherry-picking. You picked 6 years, giving you 20xx to 50xx, which is "mediocre", and also gives you 4xx to 10xx, which just so happens to include the pretty much legendary generational leaps of the  9xx and 10xx series, both with an uplift of over 40% compared to the previous generation. Usually, a generation provides more around 20 to 30% uplift. More than 40% is definitely an outlier.

I'm not really trying to defend the 50xx series. The uplift definitely is "meh", it's basically a slightly "super" version of the 40xx generation. That's a great reason to be disappointed by it, but as far as reasons for "hating it" goes, it's a pretty ridiculous one. The botched power connector would be a much better choice there. I used to check graphics cards reviews for noise, temperature, OC results etc... now you have to hope some third party manufacturer manages to release a card with a design that's not likely to burn your house down.
comments.author: @MR-vg7yn

Happy they compared it to the 4070 super ti. I still find it hard to be sold on whatever new cutting edge features they add. Ray tracking was introduced as a major selling point on 20 series cards. It wasn't worth a damn until 30 and 40 series cards largely due to hardware performance but also due to game developers. Same with resizeable bar support. What's the value proposition to buy a card with these new features. If you buy it now, in 4 years games might start implementing it. And by then your hardware will implement it so poorly you never get the value of being an early adaptor. And you will need to upgrade to see the feature you were excited about implemented well.

A "future proof" gpu purchase is basically an exstra tax you pay to maybe enjoy that new feature on one or 2 select titles durring the time that card is relevant.

Nvidia really needs to more fully separate their consumer gaming product divisions from the mothership. Since the overwhelming majority of their business has become AI-focused we've seen the consumer cards suffer more and more, while becoming outrageously expensive. The only real hope is that I do believe the things like DLSS, MFG, and "neural" rendering may very well net us greater improvements in the future than raw rasterization can. The RTX 5070 Ti is a new graphics card from Nvidia that is positioned as a mid-range option. Here are the key takeaways from the video: The RTX 5070 Ti performs well in gaming, offering a significant improvement over the RTX 4070 Ti, especially at 1440p resolution. However, the card is underwhelming compared to AMD's Radeon RX 7900 XT, which is an older card but still offers comparable performance. The 5070 Ti also offers some improvements in ray tracing and Al-based features like DLSS 3. The overall performance of the RTX 50 series is underwhelming compared to previous generations. The video concludes that Nvidia seems to be prioritizing Al applications and their shareholders over gamers, leading toa stagnation in the performance of their graphics cards. The reviewer states that he is disappointed with the performance of the RTX 50 series, as it is not a significant upgrade over previous generations. He also criticizes Nvidia for prioritizing Al and their shareholders over gamers.

comments.text:
As somebody who's never been a gen-to-gen jumper, would love to see a video at some point whose entire focus is "how old does your current hardware need to be for an upgrade to Current Gen to be worth it?" Focusing on value over time as well as up-front costs. Eg, if somebody's only just growing out of an 8yo GPU, you can probably expect they'd be hoping for their next upgrade to last at least 8 years too. Where are the points where, to the best of your knowledge of the industry, are the best value over time for people considering years-of-service into their next purchasing decision? 

For example, I'd never recommend a new card with under 16GB of vRAM for anybody hoping to hold on to it for a long while, and having the ability to ray trace seems to be the direction the games development industry is heading. I'd also want to know what encoding standards are available for each card. Would buying a used 3090 actually give me more long-term value than a 5070, given the price difference compared to feature differences, if the performance of each are acceptable to me? Also, if you were somebody who already owned a 3090, how many more "years of service" would you get out of upgrading to a 5070 versus holding on to the card you already have, which may still have quite a few more years of acceptable performance in the tank? 

I'd also be curious at what point a dedicated graphics card is worth a stand-alone purchase if you already have AMD's fairly decent onboard graphics on your CPU. What's the price per additional FPS compared to what's already included? The tipping point is definitely a lot lower for those on Intel chips (can confirm as somebody with an Intel mainboard in my Framework at the moment), but I've heard AMD's onboard graphics are actually pretty decent. How many extra FPS per dollar can you wring out from adding a low-mid tier dedicated GPU to your rig? And, for those who mainly drive a laptop with a decent dock setup when at desk (including cooling pad), similar question but for eGPUs, which have the higher cost of the enclosure and the lower benefit from the more limited data transfer speeds. 

TL;DR: Would love to see a video all about upgrade value from different types of systems, focusing on "what more you could get per dollar" instead of "what you could get if you've already decided to spend your dollars today"

comments.text:
5:10
Y'know what's neat? The CUDA cores have actually been DOWNGRADED somewhat this gen. Blackwell 2.0 CUDA, no longer supports 32-bit CUDA. That means BYE BYE PHYSX SUPPORT. That's right, your 5090 is probably slower than a 1080 Ti in PHYSX titles...

That said. Blackwell 2.0 CUDA does do simultaneous integer and floating point math on the same clock, just like Turing did. So there is AN upgrade to the cores in some capacity.

If I had to guess, I'd say NVIDIA (and their partners) can't produce enough high-quality wafers.
So they only have two options. Either they throw away the faulty wafers and raise prices, or they use the faulty wafers for lower-end cards like the RTX 5070 Ti and lower prices a little bit.
I prefer the latter option, but I wish they would explain that. Then again, no company would admit that they can't produce enough high-quality wafers. Since NVIDIA is a publicly traded company, that's even more true.

comments.text:
In early Summer 2023, I got a killer deal on my 7900-XTX. At a time when the cheapest RTX 4080 was $1230, I paid $900 for this (and its a good AIB too that retailed at $1049.99). Even back then I was happy with my purchase. AMD GPUs are no longer trash like they used to be.

In the almost 2 years I have owned it, there has only ever been a single driver issue with a single game and it was a temporary issue that was fixed with the next driver update. Other than that, its been as reliable as any of the 3 Nvidia GPUs I have owned - pleasantly surprised!

I can even Ray-Trace decently on it. Ya the performance in Ray-Tracing isn't the best but being AMD's flagship and all it can brute-force its way through with acceptable performance. I don't really care about Ray-Tracing yet, but it was fun to mess around with.

Well, I guess for my GFs upcoming PC we will have to consider AMD once again. We wanted a 5070-Ti 16GB but if we can't get one for the $750 MSRP then whichever card can actually handle 3440x1440p with high frame rates at high settings and actually sells at a decent price first will get our purchase and thats all there is to it. Im sure the 9070-XT will be fine for 3440x1440p, now its just a matter of when the pricing will drop to a reasonable level.

comments.text:
If you bought a 780 Ti on launch like I did, you got a great 1080p card for $699.  If you then upgraded to a 2080 like I did, you got a ~170% performance uplift on average at 1080p, for $699.  Marginally cheaper adjusting for inflation.    If you are looking to upgrade to this card from an RTX 2080, you will get a 160% performance uplift on average at 4k (and probably similar at 1440p).   Note this is not considering stuff like DLSS or frame gen, or RT performance, I'm talking about raw rasterization pixel pushing here.  If you can buy it at MSRP, in real dollar value, it's actually less expensive today for that similar uplift ($750 today is equal to ~$600 in late 2018 dollars).  But that's unlikely, given supply issues, so let's again look at inflation.  $699 in Sept. 2018 is equal to $880 today, which is about in line with what you can expect to pay for one of these cards if you're going to try and beat the bots tomorrow, give or take a couple bucks.  

While I do understand that this isn't some massive leap forward in value for dollar, it's also not some massive backslide.  It's not Jensen's fault that inflation shot through the roof in the past 5 years.  Is it as cheap as I'd like?  No, but really, what is?   It's in line with what you typically got if you bought a $700 video card every 5 years or so for the past decade.  If you wanna get mad about supply issues, I'm right there with ya.  If you wanna get mad about inflation, blame central banking for printing money during covid and governments for massive deficit spending.

comments.text:
This is a much better video in terms of information to explain the 50-series, and it's current state in the market, than the other previous reviews. Particularly the segment explaining the manufacturing node, lightly/moderately/non-improved RT/tensor/cuda cores vs investment in AI integration, architecture and capabilities—I think a lot of people didn't understand this, and needed to here it—and the historical pricing segment for those confused about some of the backlash from performance expectations. You did all this while also speaking in common easy to understand language without ridiculous, abstracted analogies. Bravo to the writers of this video.

Would have loved for you to have mentioned the very expensive manufacturing cost (not even including R&D) for even still manufacturing on 4N with TSMC, which is actually more expensive then it was years ago. Cheers, keep up the great work.

I just quoted a customer a $3,500+ PC with the best of everything performance wise(No extream OC Motherboard or pure bling) with the solle exceptation of an RX 7900 XTX. The reason is ilistrated right here in this video. I'm a small town IT guy that can't get an RTX GPU allocation, and for a 4k Gaming PC the best card money can buy at this time seems to be the RX 7900 XTX. Yes the RTX4080 and RTX 5070ti can beat it in Ray Tracing, but the only game that Needs Ray Tracing is Indiana Jones and unless you enable Path Tracing the 7900 XTX can still hit 60fps at 4k.

TLDR: You can get all the best of everything but the GPU now, and just upgrade when the GPU's don't cost as  much as the rest of the system plus a kidney.

comments.text: @SwainixFPV  Do a Display Driver Uninstall clear off everything from your machine related to graphics cards, restart your system and then download the latest version of AMD's software and drivers for your graphics card. Restart one more time and run a couple software benchmarking tools. If the problem persists, start doing a process of elimination on your whole machine, RAM, Motherboard, GPU itself, Power Supply Unit, etc. Maybe check your software and other programs, the Operating System, look for any malware. If you're using mods with any of your installed games, check them for any relevant updates. Sometimes it could be a hardware issue and other times it could be software.

comments.text:
My main issue is that these review videos as much as informative as they can be (thank you), these are that pushes the prices to the sky and beyond. If a reviewer said "oh, this is expensive, but still the best value graphics card" it will boost the few, who can buy these cards even at this price point, to go out and buy it. Even if it is not MSRP. You need to realize, you are the number one advertisement for these cards. Not CES, not their own expo, not their youtube videos. You are (you as all of the tech youtubers) Have you seen how much subscribers NVidia have on their YT channel? 1.6m. Literary 1/10th of yours Linus. Now I know I live in wonderland and you have many mouths to feed, thus making these videos is almost mandatory, but I'll say it anyway. You should boycott every graphics card manufacturer along all the other beautiful ppl in the tech youtube industry. If you don't promote their graphics cards, but just raise awareness in a video at launch date stating that they are overpriced AF (and don't do the benchmarks), that will be an eyeopening to all of them to either release a card that is significantly better than the previous generation (like how the 3000 was to the 2000 series) or even better, lower their prices to start competing.
I am just a sad gamer, who was stuck on a Radeon 580 since 2019 (recently upgraded to a third hand 6650XT) with a brother stuck on Radeon 570 and nephew on Radeon 560. We simply cannot afford any of the new parts. The best what we can do is buy 2nd or 3rd hand stuff and hope we are not screwed. I don't remember, I think JayZ said in a video: "PC Gaming became a rich people hobby" - and I can't agree enough with him on this.

comments.text: To hopefully beat the dummies to the point: generational uplift is not just important for the people pointlessly upgrading every two years. If you are on a card from two generations ago (like the 3070, which is nearly 4 1/2 years old and only has 8GB of VRAM), it no longer makes sense to buy the new card, when it performs so similarly to the previous gen (in this case the 4070TI/TI Super. The fact that extra frames will now mean varying levels of high latency and greater power draw makes it even harder to justify buying this card for 30-series owners that are at the same tier. Waiting a few months will allow you to buy a 40-series card used that will be nearly as performant in most circumstances, and for less money (see JayzTwoCents' videos on 5070TI pricing).

comments.text:
In the end, we as gamers are put between rock and a hard place.
If you want Ray Tracing, it is obvious to buy RTX rather than Radeon but RTX doesn't have big enough VRAM.
If you want big enough VRAM, it is obvious to buy Radeon rather than RTX but that big VRAM is pretty useless when the processing is slow.

Seeing how RX 9070 XT was rumoured, I really lost my faith.
I thought Intel with its B580 would be the saviour for mid range and budget gamers until... their GPU won't perform well with budget CPU. The idea of needing the latest generation of CPU with pretty high price to be paired with mid range GPU is a bit weird and a bit inbalance since you can simply allocate money from good CPU to get better GPU.

So, yeah... My expectation on them (Nvidia, AMD, and Intel) are low.
If somehow Radeon launches a GPU that is below my already low expectation... yeah... they will have the worst launch but hey... people can't buy Nvidia's newest graphic so someone will still buy it anyway.

There's absolutely no reason for me to upgrade my GPU at all, my RTX 3070 still feels a little overpowered for literally any game I decide to play.

I wish I could find modern and newer games fun, but I cannot find a single game that I enjoy at all, I refund every single newish game I buy, and it's not even like I'm an old man or insanely nostolgic about these things.

comments.text: When it comes to Frame Gen, DLSS 4, etc I'd personally get more out of a review if it was like the 8k gaming video you did the other day. More opinion based stuff, in addition to the  data driven review here. A small group of your team, using one setup, playing different games on different settings and voicing opinions on how they feel the experience is. I want to know if these are features worth having or if they're just going to be turned off. Only then does the raw data become useful in a purchasing decision. While a 5070ti might be worse in direct raw performance than a 7900XTX, how valid is that comparison in terms of real world usage? If the real world scenario is you'd generally use DLSS and Frame Gen on a 5070Ti and you would use FSR and no frame gen on an 7900XTX, or whatever the case is, I would actually like to see that comparison.

comments.text: @JeremyBell Depends on what you're after. If your focus is on compute power, Nvidia still comes out every time. But if you're bottlenecked by vRAM, Intel is actually providing much better price-to-performance there! It might not matter so much to gaming workloads, though with the way games are going with their texture sizes I'm not even entirely sure about that one, but with other types of workloads, that vRAM actually being available on low-tier cards is an absolute godsend for not having to shunt data back and forth to main system memory, something which is extremely slow to do compared to clock speeds. comments.text: Wym? Genuinely asking. I thought avg fps is a go-to benchmark since it measures your avg gaming experience. Why would 1% of lowest fps matter?
comments.author: @Grzybo93

comments.text: @Grzybo93  the 1% lows reflect how smooth or stuttery a game will be when you play it. if you have an avg of 120fps, and 1% lows of 110, it's going to feel smooth as butter. if you avg the same 120 fps, but with 1% lows at 50, the game will feel very inconsistent and choppy. avg fps is good for measuring performance, 1% lows are good for measuring how consistent that performance is.
comments.author: @Eclypse-1

comments.text:
@Grzybo93  
Because you don't want to play a game with nominally high fps, but which constantly stutters. It is way better to play with consistent non-stuttery fps, even if its average is nominally lower.
comments.author: @MachoMaster

comments.text:
@Grzybo93 no, it is the 1% lows that define the experience.

If you average fps is 100, but the game drops to 20 fps every few seconds (stuttering), that will ruin the experience.

But if the average fps is 60, and it only drops to 50,  you will have a much smoother experience, as there are no distracting sudden drops.

The Arc A770 is famous for being a card with decent average fps, but lots of stuttering due to bad drivers.

The 1% lows reveals stuttering, average dont show that.



Consistency is more important than raw power.
comments.author: @rj7250a

comments.text: @Grzybo93  avg fps doesn't account for stutters and stuff like that, while 1% lows shows basically the worst your FPS got. For example your average FPS can show like 80-90 but every few seconds  you get a 0.2 second stutter, your average FPS will still show around 80-85 but 1% low will correctly show that your FPS severely dipped at times and this number will be a lot lower, another situation is when different parts of your session had FPS dips, or also micro stutters, etc, there are probably better examples but that's the gist. 1% lows represent your real gaming experience a lot better than avg fps

comments.author: @ssc00p

comments.text: @ZaeBae22  I would just say that if you're going from an Nvidia to AMD card I would download the full latest Adrenalin version for the card you will buy to your PC. Then it is a best practice to use something like DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) from a reputable site like Guru3D and use it to remove all Nvidia drivers. Once that is done I would shut down and swap out to the AMD card, boot up and install the Adrenalin driver package. The layout for Adrenalin will be different from what you are used to with Nvidia control panel but most everything you need is in there. Performance tab let's you adjust overclock/undervolt settings, definitely turn on SAM (Smart Access Memory). If this is grayed out or unselectable depending on your motherboard you can enable it in your BIOS. Once SAM is activated I would say you are ready to play. If you want an even deeper dive into your settings options Ancient Gameplays on YouTube has a bunch of deep dives on AMD Adrenalin. If you want to be extra sure you're getting the best experience make sure Windows is up to date, check that your RAM is set to DOCP (Ryzen) or XMP (Intel) so your 1% lows are consistent. Any specific questions just @me.
comments.author: @ji3qu

comments.text: ​ @ZaeBae22 when switching you should boot into safemode and run DDU to properly uninstall the Nvidia driver, doing a normal uninstall can give weird issues

Returned a used 4080 I bought at a great price that had some issues and replaced it with a 7900xtx. I'm happy with it. Use it exclusively for 4K OLED gaming.  The internet will consistently lead you down the wrong path. What is more laughable when people choose a 'side' green vs red. I'm GPU company agnostic. 

The GPU market is toast, Nvidia is focused on their real money maker which is servicing the AI market, and gamers getting GPUs is the least of their concern. 

I tried for a 5080 but yeah thanks Nvidia -- no supply with their paper launch. 

I'm riding out with my 7900xtx--- hoping that AMD comes out with a 9900xtx late 2025 or early 2026--- also holding out for the used market to settle and maybe try a 4090 or even get a 5090 if supply eventually increases by Nvidia board partners and prices hit closer to MSRP this fall/winter. 

A lot of wishes if/could----

comments.text: @JeremyBell  I would say that if you are experiencing 1% low issues and stuttering something else on your PC could have been a factor.  LTT and Gamers Nexus review charts show that the 7800 XT 1% and 0.1% lows are competitive with NVIDIA cards across a suite of games.  If you were experiencing lows that that fall outside of those values it is very likely you were seeing a bottleneck from other PC hardware, in-game settings or a Windows issue. Your individual experience does not prove an "AMD Dip" exists anymore than my reply proves it false.  However, charts across multiple games and multiple runs for LTT and GamersNexus do prove your experience was likely an outlier rather than the norm. Otherwise it would be a top clickbait title for every reputable YouTuber.

comments.text: I bought a 7900XTX. I have only ever owned AMD cards, and here is why I am returning it and have a 5070TI on the way. AMD has always been the best for native price to performance. And before the 7900XTX I purchased mid-low cards, think 5700XT, 6600XT, R9, 270, ect. In this tier range, AMD kills it, because frames matter the most. DLSS and RT and not very helpful when you cant break 60FPS. The 7900XTX performance is great. Paired with a 9800X3D, and it destroys games at max settings on 165Hz monitor. The problem: now in a "high end range", the drivers and software actually matter. There are games that I cannot run max settings without visual bugs or lack of textures, there are adverse visual effects such as in GTAV with lights appearing to distort objects the same way a clear gas would, and in several games, an issue that looks similar to a screen tear, but not very noticeable (unless you are playing FPS games). My point is, I don't think AMD is the best option outside of value. If I were looking to spend in the ballpark of $450, I would get a 7800XT and be very happy with it, but not in the mid-high to high-end range

comments.text: @robertt9342  Very simple from a business standpoint. You have product A with a 50% profit margin and dominant market share, and product B that you can sell for a 10% profit margin because of strong competition. Both products use the exact same raw materials, but the one with lower profit margin has lower demand, and consumes way more of that raw material. Also, the raw material is allocated to you in a finite quantity and is only produced by a single manufacturer. Are you going to make more of product A or more of product B?
